title-group.subtitle: The impact of governing parties on spending in Canada

bio.title: Author biography
bio.p: Marc André Bodet is a SSHRC Post-Doctoral Fellow in the Department of Political Science, University of British Columbia, Canada. His research interests include electoral politics and public policy. Recent publications have appeared in Comparative Political Studies, Journal of Election, Public Opinion and Parties and Social Science Quarterly.

author-notes.corresp: Marc André Bodet, 1866 Main Mall, Vancouver, Canada, V6T 1E6. Email: mabodet@mail.mcgill.ca

abstract.p: This article tests the role of governing parties in budgetary policy in Canada. Using federal expenditure data in policy domains related to defence, economic and social policies, we estimate party effects on government spending since 1965. Results suggest that, holding other variables constant, a partisan effect exists in most policy domains under study. Furthermore, multipartyism tends to impact the role of parties in public spending.

disp-quote.p: ‘Thus both the government and the voters are interested in marginal alterations in the structure of government activities' – Anthony Downs 1

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Modern representative democracies face serious challenges, particularly when it comes to reinvesting public money. An almost inevitable consequence is the neglect of certain interests while others, more widespread or better organized, reap greater benefits (Dahl, 1956; Madison, 1787). Political tensions are both managed and fostered through interaction between partisan interests, parties themselves and rigid institutional rules. Frictions inevitably emerge.

In Canada, criticizing how political institutions perform has become a research field on its own (Cairns, 1977; Clarke et al., 1984; Docherty, 1997; Savoie, 1999; Simpson, 2001). There is a considerable body of work that explores the ways in which these institutions may limit the relationship between public preferences and policy. The Single-Member Plurality (SMP) system has come under fire, for instance, for distorting the relationship between seats and votes (Lijphart, 1994; Powell, 2000). 2 Division of power also matters. Federalism is often described as confusing for citizens, since it makes the task of punishing and rewarding the right level of government difficult (Anderson, 2006); governments are, as a consequence, not subject to the same level of public oversight. And the policies of any single government may be conflated with the policies of another.

Separate from the representation of public preferences in policy is the representation of parties in policy. Do parties make a difference? (Blais et al., 1993; Rose, 1984). SMP may have quite a different effect in this regard since it tends to produce strong (single-party) majority governments, and partisan effects may be comparatively pronounced (Blais et al., 2010). And the effects of SMP are likely enhanced by an unchallenged executive-centred decision-making process, with a primary role given to the Prime Minister and close aides (Goldenberg, 2006; Savoie, 1999). Strong seat majorities in the House of Commons give enough latitude to the executive to implement bold public policies (Franks, 1987). However, federalism may pull in the opposite direction, since any one government's policy-making must be concerned with, or perhaps work around, another's. Put differently, partisan effects may be more constrained because governments themselves are more constrained by jurisdictional boundaries.

Beyond the considerable role played by institutions, a fundamental feature of developed states is at play: yearly change in government activities remains incremental most of the time, and marginal more often than not. This feature is central to a number of theories of policy-making (see, e.g., Baumgartner and Jones, 1993; Cohen et al., 1972; Downs, 1957, 1967; Lindblom, 1959; Wildavsky, 1964). Even though these theories are irreconcilable on numerous instances, they all agree that policy-making is fundamentally inertial. Consequently, if we are looking for partisan effects in policy, we must remain realistic about the magnitude of those effects. Citizens of democratic states should expect party politics to play a role in budgetary policy for sure, though possibly only at the margins.

sec.title: Sources of policy change
sec.p: As a starting point, it is important to identify what drives change in policy. The literature teaches us that a series of factors are at play. First, macro-economic context is an essential factor that explains in part why policy varies over the years (see, for example, Cutright, 1965; Dye, 1966; Friedman, 1971; Hallerberg and Basinger, 1998; Owens, 1990). Change in the economic environment can incite governments to invest, disinvest or redirect money toward other policy domains. Some domains may also be more influenced by changes in the economic context than others. For example, a government may substantially increase its spending in labour training when unemployment increases among unskilled workers. The second factor at play is previous policy decisions. As stated above, yearly changes in government activities are incremental most of the time, and marginal more often than not. A large proportion of spending decisions is thus driven by what has been done in the past. Thirdly, it has been suggested that democratic systems tend to be responsive to public opinion shifts (see Devine, 1970; Soroka and Wlezien, 2010; Stimson et al., 1995; Wlezien, 1995). Opinion representation plays a role in policy that is arguably captured by party politics, at least in part. But its proponents have shown with great success that opinion representation is relevant and substantial.

The fourth and last factor at play in policy is the main focus of this article. We expect party politics (through partisan representation) to play a significant role in policy. Political parties perform multiple tasks in a democratic system. There are heuristic tools for voters who do not have the time or the resources to take positions on all issues (see, e.g., Hobolt, 2007; Rahn, 1993). They are also providers of coherent policy packages to facilitate voters' choices (Klingemann et al., 1994). Moreover, they systematically represent groups over longer periods of time, groups that then become natural constituencies. Parties are also vehicles of representation that benefit from institutional legitimacy conferred by the electoral process: those that are successful at securing votes and seats in general elections are arguably more successful at influencing, if not affecting change in the policy-making process.

sec.title: The role of parties in policy
sec.p: Over the past half century, students of parliamentary democracies have consistently placed parties at the centre of the political process (see, e.g., Downs, 1957; Epstein, 1983; Schattschneider, 1942). We know that party politics is a fundamental aspect of elections (Austen-Smith and Banks, 1988), the parliamentary process (Cox, 1987) and cabinet formation (Strom et al., 1994). But what about the role of political parties in budgetary policy? Findings in the comparative literature remain inconclusive, while very little has been done in Canada alone. We argue that a combination of case selection and deficiency in operationalization are to blame for the current lack of consensus. Country-specific studies are part of the solution.

Early empirical work in public policy suggests that variations in public spending are solely the consequence of economic (Cutright, 1965; Dye, 1966) and demographic fluctuations (Wilenski, 1975) conditioned by rigid budgetary incrementalism (Davis et al., 1966). This work does not leave much space, if any, for a role of parties in policy. Beginning in the late 1970s, however, a body of work began to challenge this conclusion. Scholars then started asking the following question: Do parties make a difference (DPMD)?

A group of scholars led by Francis G. Castles has played a fundamental role in answering this question. Building on a previous study that had shown there seems to exist a relationship between party vote-shares and welfare spending (Castles and McKinlay 1979), these comparative scholars brought more evidence to support their conclusions regarding the role of parties in a series of book chapters that looked at party effects in multiple dimensions of economic policies (Castles, 1982). But this ground-breaking work was not enough to dissipate doubts. The role of parties in policy was rebutted several years later by Solano (1983), who concludes that partisanship is not associated with government expenditure. These early conclusions must be treated with caution, however, since their use of a single year’s data prevents generalization.

Swank (1988) uses a better specification to answer the same question. He tests, among other hypotheses, the impact of parties on spending using a relatively simple (though rather robust) cross-sectional model where the left-hand side variable is the change in domestic expenditures between the first and the last years of the two periods under study. He shows that, between 1960 and 1973, parties that were furthest to the right spent less than their centrist and leftist counterparts. However, that effect disappears in later years as centrist parties become more prone to higher spending than their counterparts on the Left and the Right. Swank’s estimates do not suffer from certain shortcomings of ‘real’ cross-sectional analysis (sample selection or omitted variable bias, for example). That said, given that budgetary change is annual, and governments change regularly, important information may be lost in the aggregating process.

Fortunately, time-series analyses are also available for similar pools of countries. Looking at the expansion of government revenues in 18 industrialized democracies over 15 years (1960–75), Cameron (1978) shows that the partisan effect is stronger in large and closed economies, but that it becomes less salient in smaller and more market-oriented economies that are dependent on international contingencies. Is this also true for public expenditures? Using a sample of 12 European industrialized countries, Rice (1986) finds no systematic partisan effect. Again, economic factors seem to drive public spending. However, Blais et al. (1993, 1996) do find support for the partisanship hypothesis using a sample of 15 liberal democracies over 27 years (1960–87). Blais et al. first conclude that party effects are conditioned by the electoral system and government experience (1993), before disconfirming the SMP hypothesis in their reassessment (1996). Keman (2002) finds mixed support for partisan effects on welfare spending in both members of the European Union and of the Organisation of Economic and Co-operation Development (OECD) countries, using data covering 1975 to 1995. He concludes that ‘parties do matter, but in a rather varied way (222)’ with a strong effect on the size of the state but a mitigated effect on welfare spending. 3

The list of all the research conducted on the role of parties in public policy is overwhelming. One can find in the literature positive support regarding the impact of parties on investment in health and welfare policy (Comiskey, 1983), size of the public sector (Cusack, 1997) and cash transfers (Hicks and Swank, 1984). Different contexts have also been studied. Frey (1978) concludes that partisanship only matters when government is popular; Oatley (1999) tests with success the robustness of partisanship in open economies; Schmidt (1996) argues that majoritarian systems are more prone to partisan overspending; while Breunig (2003) shows instead that partisan control of the government is more important in the American context than in the United Kingdom 4 and Germany.

In a nutshell, controversy is still alive and well. But how can we explain such diverse conclusions in the comparative literature? This is especially puzzling since most of this research is conducted on a limited sample of liberal democracies. Diverse findings are thus not a consequence of wildly different samples. That said, there are at least two reasons that come to mind: case selection and deficiency in operationalization. Case selection seems particularly problematic here, since very few authors discuss the reasons behind their decision to include a wide array of polities with such different historical backgrounds and institutional designs. In other words, the literature may not compare ‘comparable cases' (Lijphart, 1971). Pooling countries together with different electoral systems, divisions of power and parliamentary rules creates heterogeneity that cannot be captured by the inclusion of simple dummy variables: institutions not only induce governing parties to spend more or less, they might also push them to spend differently (Franzese, 2002; Swank, 2002). Second, there is variation, and in each case certain deficiencies, in the way partisanship is operationalized in the literature. A good number of studies make use of simple ideological classification (e.g., left/centre/right) in comparative framework; others use ideological scales; others, electoral platforms. As we see below, focusing on a single country eliminates most of these issues.

sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: Two hypotheses are studied here. First, we test to see whether governing parties have an impact on budgetary policy in Canada. We focus our attention on four policy domains: (1) protection of persons and properties, (2) regional planning and development, (3) labour, employment and immigration, and (4) social services. We discuss in more detail what specific policies are included in these categories in the following section. Since we are interested in meso-level budgetary policy, we remain agnostic regarding the mechanism through which parties in government influence spending in each policy domain. Three parties have been in government in Canada since the early 1960s: The Liberal Party of Canada (LPC), the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada (PCP) and the Conservative Party of Canada (CPC). The LPC has been considered the natural government party for most of the twentieth century (Carty, 1992). It stands for a strong and centralized welfare state, equality of opportunity and multiculturalism. Its dominance has been challenged first by two landslide electoral victories of Brian Mulroney’s Progressive Conservatives in the mid-1980s and then by two minority governments of Stephen Harper’s Conservatives. Though there exist considerable differences between the late PCP and the existing CPC, 5 both parties do stand for a moderate brand of social conservatism, a limited role for the government and a strong emphasis on economic liberty. Both incarnations have also enjoyed strong and consistent electoral support in the more rural and suburban districts of the country, especially outside Quebec. This first hypothesis will be confirmed if there is a significant difference in Liberal and Conservative spending behaviours. Our expectations regarding the direction of partisan effects in specific policy domains are consistent with governing parties' branding. LPC budgets should put more emphasis in labour, immigration and anti-poverty policies 6 and PCP/CPC budgets should invest more on policies related to law and order and rural communities.

The second hypothesis states that the shift from a two-and-a-half party system (1964–93) to a multiparty system (1994–present) conditions partisan effects. The third party system was characterized by the dominance of the Liberal Party until the late 1970s, the relative weakness of the Progressive Conservative Party among Francophones and Maritimers and the existence of smaller parties on the fringes of the political spectrum, such as the New Democratic Party (NDP) and the Social Credit (Carty et al., 2000). Progressive Conservative Premier Brian Mulroney managed to alter the political landscape during the 1984 and 1988 elections, but a series of failed constitutional reforms and minor scandals led to an implosion of his party and the rise of the fourth party system in 1993. During the 1993 general election, the Bloc Québécois took advantage of the frustration felt by Quebec voters about the lack of openness of English Canada to Quebec’s political grievances to win a large majority of seats in that province, running on a separatist platform. The Western Canada populist fraction of the conservative movement (Reform Party) benefited from the opposite sentiment in the population, gathering strong support among Western Canada voters who were tired of Ottawa-centred politics. The PCP was almost destroyed during the election and was left with a meagre two seats in the House of Commons. The coexistence of two national parties on the right side of the political spectrum left the LPC unchallenged in its quest for power. The Liberals made the most of this situation until the 2004 election when a merger between the main conservative forces brought the political system to its current state of successive minority governments and multipartyism. The nature of these two party systems and the spectacular reorganization that occurred in the 1993 election are both symptoms of our institutional context. First, the federal structure frames the political discourse in a way that makes managing a ‘national government’ quite challenging. Second, an SMP system shapes parties' electoral strategies (Cox, 1997; Duverger, 1954) but also allows important shifts in seat representation across elections. Related to this issue, Sartori (1976) has argued quite convincingly that two-party and moderate multiparty systems – such as the Canadian third party system – betray centripetal dynamics with strong competition at the centre, while multiparty systems with stronger ideological differences show centrifugal dynamics and competition on both the fringes of the political spectrum and the moderate centre. In other words, partisan effects are more likely to appear (or become even more salient) in multiparty systems such as the third (and current) party system in Canada.

Both hypotheses are tested within the same statistical model. We discuss in a following section how to disentangle partisan effects in the third and fourth systems, conditional on other important factors in the model.

sec.title: Model specification and data
sec.p: Using Statistics Canada’s government spending matrices and macro-economic data, 7 time series of five policy domains are constructed covering 43 budgets from 1965 to 2008. Among these, we count 30 Liberal, 10 Progressive Conservative and 3 Conservative budgets. Fiscal years begin on 1 April and end on 31 March of the following year. That means, for example, spending for FY1984 goes from 1 April 1984 to 31 March 1985. Macro-economic and political data have been adjusted accordingly.

Time-series data are more often than not plagued with non-stationarity. The most common solution to this problem is to differentiate variables when necessary. But this option is fortunately not the only possibility. In cases where the relationship of interest includes one or many level variables, de-trending can purge – at least in part – these variables from their non-stationary process. De-trending simply consists in regressing a non-stationary (explained or explanatory) variable on a constant and a time trend and then, gathers the residuals: 1

De-trending is not a silver bullet against non-stationarity, but it is the best tool available when one wants to avoid first difference transformation. Time-series data also remain prone to autoregressive processes (AR). We thus opt for an Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model with autoregressive of order 1.

This article focuses on four policy domains: (1) Protection of persons and properties, (2) regional planning and development, (3) labour, employment and immigration, and (4) social services. These domains were selected for three reasons. First, availability of data: they were among the 13 domains available from Statistics Canada for the entire time period. Second, we want to avoid shared or concurrent jurisdictions between federal and provincial governments such as Health and Education to make sure we measure policy-makers' decisions in an environment mostly free of intergovernmental constraints. 8 Third, these four domains represent a good balance between social and economic policies. The bulk of protection of persons and properties is related to national defence and civil security spending (mostly federal police forces). It also includes management of federal courts and prisons. Social services cover income maintenance programmes such as sales tax credit, family allowances and other social assistance policies aimed at poorer citizens. Labour, employment and immigration is a large policy domain that includes employment programmes, re-insertion initiatives and other labour-related government spending. It also includes policies related to working conditions in Canada. This domain includes programmes aimed at new and future Canadians and visa programmes. Finally, regional planning and development refers to programmes aimed at helping impoverished rural or peripheral regions of Canada, notably in the Maritimes and in rural Quebec. Urban renewal programmes and land rehabilitation are good examples of policies included in this domain. As discussed in the introduction, it is more appropriate to think of spending policy in terms of yearly changes. Incrementalism indeed teaches us that policy-makers make decisions in these terms rather than in absolute dollars spent (Wildavsky, 1964). Moreover, first differentiation reduces the risk of spuriousness, omitted variable bias, and it increases the efficiency of estimators (Frees, 2004). Keep in mind that the Dickey-Fuller interpolated critical value for our sample size is 2.611 at 90 percent of confidence. A t-statistic above that critical value means that we fail to reject the null hypothesis of non-stationarity. In column 1, the test suggests that there is non-stationarity in five out of six continuous variables under study. De-trending reduces this number to only two. Finally, the differentiation eliminates non-stationarity in all spending series and in unemployment rates. We are thus left with inflation rate, which still shows symptoms of non-stationarity. Fortunately, the transformation of our explained variables (spending) greatly reduces risks of spurious associations.

Figure 1 gives an idea of how our dependent variables are distributed over time. Full dots represent LPC budgets and hollow dots PCP/CPC. At first sight, yearly changes might not seem considerable, but keep in mind that these are yearly changes in ratio of spending in a given policy domain over total government spending. That means a change of one percentage point may represents hundreds of millions of dollars. Moreover, as stated in the Introduction, the nature of policy-making in a developed state like Canada should only allow changes at the margins. Consequently, the yearly variance observed is what we should expect.

sec.p: Let us look at the right-hand side of the model. Our strategy consists in controlling for other known factors of influence and then in seeing if the factor of interest still shows signs of significance in terms of both efficiency and magnitude. In the case of policy change, we would thus need to control for the macro-economic context, the previous policy output and opinion representation, and see if partisan representation still emerges. These first two other factors are included in our model. Opinion representation is not. We justify this exclusion by the fact that opinion and partisan representation are closely related, especially around election time. If the citizenry wants less emphasis on labour policy, it can support a party that advocates for less spending in that domain. However, this proximity between opinion and party behaviour may weaken when elections are not around the corner. 10 For the sake of this article, we consider that the impact of opinion representation on policy is channelled through partisan representation, though arguably inconsistently. Keeping that in mind, our model incorporates six covariates, one interaction term and an intercept.

First, we include the absolute (lagged) level of spending ratio. As the fraction of total expenditures dedicated to a policy domain increases, it becomes more difficult to justify an increase in the amount of money invested as its opportunity costs soon become unbearable. In other words, past spending decisions condition change in policy. Our expectation is thus to find a negative and significant relation between fraction of spending at time t − 1 and change in fraction of spending between time t and t − 1. Two macro-economic factors are included in the model. First, unemployment rate is a proxy for the economic situation at the moment when the budget is written. Its impact depends on the policy domain in question. Domains related to labour and economic development should see an increase in relative spending in difficult times since they are important government tools to encourage economic growth. However, there might be serious fiscal pressures on the government in recession, making cuts in other policy domains inevitable. We use contemporary unemployment rate for social services and labour, employment and immigration since spending in these domains is highly sensitive to the current state of the economy. The first lag is preferred for the other three domains. We also include lagged inflation rate, as high volatility in the price structure might influence budgetary spending. We are agnostic regarding the impact of this factor since, on the one hand, inflation might provide additional revenue through income and sales taxes (Friedman, 1971), while, on the other hand, inflation might incite government to cut or redirect public spending to cool down the economy (Hallerberg and Basinger, 1998; Owens, 1990). To control for the electoral business cycle (Blomber and Hess, 2003; Tufte, 1978), an index is included using Franzese’s measure (Franzese, 2002). This measure is more precise than a simple dummy variable since it takes into account the time of year that the election is called. The first day of each ‘electoral year’ is fixed at 1 April to accord with the budgetary calendar. A negative relation would be expected between the contemporaneous electoral business cycle and change in spending since governing parties seeking re-election have incentives to boost spending in the months prior to the vote to increase their popularity (Nordhaus, 1975; Rogoff and Sibert, 1988). However, we make use of the first lag to take into account the expectation of the governing party before presenting the budget. The relation should thus be positive. Canada does not follow a fixed election calendar. Consequently, it would be surprising if estimates associated with Franzese’s index turn out to be statistically significant. sec.title: Estimation and results
sec.p: Hypothesis testing is conducted using an ARIMA model with an autoregressive process of order 1. The statistical model includes seven variables: four continuous, two dichotomous and one interaction. The regressand is a differentiated variable but all the regressors are level variables, lagged or contemporaneous. The use of Canada as a case study also limits the number of observations to 43 budget years. Before looking at the partisan and party system effects, we briefly discuss the magnitudes of control variable estimates. Full results are presented in Table 2 .

caption.p: ARIMA estimates – predictors of change in spending ratio.

fn.p: N = 43; Robust standard errors in parentheses.

sec.p: Controlling for other relevant covariates, the correlation between yearly changes in the fraction of total spending for a given policy domain and absolute (lagged) level of spending ratio is negative, consistent and statistically significant across domains. These results are in line with our expectations. As the proportion of spending invested in a given policy domain increases, there is less room for additional increases. Regarding the impact of unemployment rate on spending behaviour, the results are as expected for labour, employment and immigration, and social services as estimates are positive and significant. An increase of one percentage point at time t − 1 leads to an increase of between a third and half a percentage point in the spending ratio. Inflation also leads to an increase in relative spending in labour, immigration and employment. However, the economic context does not seem to influence spending in other domains much. Estimates also show that the electoral business cycle has a systematic effect on relative spending in protection of persons and properties as well as on relative spending on labour, employment and immigration. The effect is positive for the former and negative for the latter.

It remains quite difficult to interpret party and party system effects in Table 1. To overcome this difficulty, Table 3 gives linear combinations of party differences for the four policy domains under study in the third and fourth party systems (PS). 11 In a previous section, we stated that we expect Liberal governments to be more prone to invest in labour, immigration and anti-poverty policies and PCP/CPC to invest more in law and order and policies aimed at rural communities. This means that Liberal governments should be more sympathetic to labour, employment, immigration, and social service policy and Conservatives should invest more in protection of persons and properties and regional planning and development.

caption.p: Party effects in five policy domains.

fn.p: N = 43; Robust standard errors in parentheses.

sec.p: A positive and statistically significant coefficient means an increase in the rate of relative investment in the given policy domain by Liberal governments, a coefficient that is not statistically different from 0 means no partisan difference, and a negative and statistically significant coefficient means an increase in the rate of relative investment in the given policy domain by PCP or CP governments.

Protection of persons and properties shows a partisan difference in the fourth party system only. The three budgets presented by the Conservative Party since 1994 have seen, taking into account the other covariates, an additional increase in the fraction of total spending of 0.328 percentage points relative to Liberal budgets. To give a sense of how important this difference is, the partisan effect represents more than two standard deviations of the fraction of total spending related to protection of persons and properties in the fourth party system. There seems to be no partisan effect in the third party system though the estimates have the expected sign. Is there a party system effect? The magnitude of the interactive term suggests that there is a statistically significant difference of 0.3 percentage points in favour of the latter party system. The level of confidence is above 90 percent.

Regional planning and development covers a series of programmes designed to help impoverished regions of Canada that need to re-invigorate their economic landscape. The money is directed, for instance, toward rural regions in the Maritimes that have been hit by the fishing crisis and rural Quebec areas which are dependent on primary industries. The third party system does not show a significant partisan effect, as Progressive Conservative and Liberal governments tend to follow a similar spending pattern. The situation is quite different in the fourth party system since Liberal budgets tend to be more generous by a yearly margin of 0.115 percentage points. The effect is barely significant at a 90 percent level of confidence but is far from trivial as this amount represents more than one standard deviation of the regressor. There is no statistically significant party system effect for this policy domain.

Changes in spending behaviour in labour, employment and immigration are influenced in part by the economic context. This is why we opt for the inclusion of the contemporaneous unemployment rate as a control. Partisan and party system effects are thus freed from the impact of the economy on the labour market. In the third party system, the partisan effect is significant at a 95 percent level of confidence, as Liberals spend 0.077 percentage points more than Progressive Conservative governments. This roughly equals half a standard deviation of the regressor. The partisan difference remains positive and significant in the fourth party system and increases subtly to 0.104 percentage points, or little more than half a standard deviation, at a level of confidence above 90 percent. However, this consistency means that no party system effect can emerge at an acceptable level of confidence.

As discussed above, social services include all sorts of transfer payments to citizens, such as family allowances. This is why contemporaneous unemployment rate is included instead of a lag to control for ‘mechanical’ changes in spending due to the economic context. Consequently, partisan and party system effects are purged from confounding factors. In the third party system, Liberal governments increased spending significantly more than Progressive Conservative governments by an average magnitude of 0.242 percentage points, or half a standard deviation. In the fourth party system, the partisan effect is inverted as Liberal governments are spending less than the Conservatives by a margin of 0.264 percentage points. Obviously, the party system effect is significant and quite important. The partisan effect changes by a strong 0.506 percentage points as Liberals have become less inclined to invest in social service policies since 1994. This might seem surprising at first sight, but research conducted on the impact of the ‘Third Way’ in Canadian politics has shown that Chrétien governments' spending decisions have had serious negative consequences on poorer Canadians (Bashevkin, 2002). Another explanation is a change in parameters of intergovernmental transfers that could have occurred during the Chrétien/Martin administration. 12 The two explanations are not contradictory.

sec.title: Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: What can we make of these results? Two hypotheses are tested here: (1) governing parties have an impact on budgetary policy in Canada, and (2) the shift from a two-and-a-half party system (1964 to 1993) to a multiparty system (1994–today) conditions that effect. The first hypothesis finds some support in all four domains under study. These partisan effects are marginal and sometimes inconsistent, but certainly not trivial. This is especially true if one keeps in mind that yearly effects cumulate over four to five-year mandates. For example, the cumulative Liberal difference on spending behaviour related to Labour, employment and immigration in the third party system over a four-year period is associated with an additional increase in the fraction of total expenditures equal to 0.308 percentage points. Controlling for other relevant factors, the impact is even more important for protection of persons and property in the current party system, as a period of three years of Conservative government adds 0.984 percentage points relative to a Liberal government. And lest this figure seems rather small, consider the following: this represents a shift of almost one percentage point of total government spending; that is, hundreds of millions of dollars poured into protection of persons and property.

To a certain extent the results also support the second hypothesis. Two out of four domains show party system effects that reach statistical significance. Protection of persons and property exhibits the strongest difference as the Conservative Party increases on average the fraction of spending dedicated to that domain in the fourth party system relative to the third party system by an additional 0.3 percentage points, or almost one standard deviation of the dependent variable. This finding supports the argument made by Sartori about the ‘run from the centre’ that characterizes large parties when the electoral market becomes more competitive. But we cannot find systematic empirical support in other domains. Some might argue that recent minority governments in Canada could be in part responsible for the estimated party system effect. We tend to agree. But we do not have enough data to test this hypothesis satisfactorily. The good news is that the impact of minority governments should be in the same direction as the effect of multipartyism, thus consistent with our findings.

The large comparative literature on budgetary policy-making has remained inconclusive about the impact of government composition on public spending. As discussed in the literature review, numerous reasons explain the lack of consensus among interested scholars. First of all, the plurality of methodological choices – sample selection and operationalization of budgetary policy-making for example – has made the process of cumulative knowledge more difficult. The choice of level of analysis is also questionable for some parts of the literature. It is indeed more challenging to isolate partisan budgetary policy-making when one uses aggregated spending data. We believe this article overcomes most of the current challenges that the field is facing. We focus on a single case (the Canadian federal government) and benefit from numerous advantages by doing so. For example, our expectations become clearer since we do not have to create artificial partisan categories to lump together parties from different countries. The other main benefit from looking at Canada is the especially good quality of data. We use policy domains instead of larger spending categories and thus can let the estimates express different relationships in different domains. This is how, for example, we can say that the Conservatives are spending less on labour and immigration policies but more on police and national defence.

Do parties make a difference in budgetary policy? The answer in Canada is a definite yes. If there are constraints imposed by federalism and the incremental nature of developed states' policy-making, these seem to be at least partly overcome by a combination of a majoritarian system of elections and an executive-centred decision-making process. For sure, there is a good amount of friction in certain policy domains that limits the role of parties in budgetary policy. But governing parties are still able to influence public spending. The magnitude of partisan effects appears to be rather subtle. But small effects add up over time. The systematic influence of parties on budgetary decisions, even at the margins, has a considerable effect over the long term. This finding provides fresh insights into the study of budgetary policy in Canada, but also provides a method to test similar hypotheses in other parliamentary systems. This new approach will hopefully clarify our understanding of the role of governing parties in policy.
